column1: #Text=[0006] In a coherent receiver, the QPSK incoming optical signal is mixed with a strong local oscillators to produce in-phase (I) and in-quadrature (Q) outputs.
#Text=I and Q components of the output optical signal are converted into electrical signals by a set of photodetectors.
#Text=In the preferred configuration four balanced photodetectors are used to recover QPSK encoded data.
#Text=[0007] Data transmission multiplexing light of two orthogonal polarizations via the same optical channel allows doubling the data rate.
#Text=At the receiver side, the orthogonal polarizations are split by a polarization beam splitter, and the light of each orthogonal polarization is detected separately.

#Text=[0008] There is still a need to increase the transmission rate and provide a reliable detection scheme to improve the high-rate data processing at the receiver side, and the present invention addresses this problem thus allowing achieving more reliable systems operating at higher data rates.

#Text=[0009] A number of architectural solutions have been proposed in order to reduce the data rate at the receiver, to split high rate flow into a number of parallel branches and process lower rate signal in each branch digitally.
#Text=In particular this approach is useful in systems that use standard ADCs with a sampling rate close to the Nyquist rate (e.g 25 Gsps).
#Text=[0010] The WDM system of the present invention includes multiple channels, each channel being able to transmit up to 1 TBit/s data stream.
#Text=It is achieved by forming the channel bandwidth as a set of non-overlapping spectral bands being orthogonal to each other.
#Text=Transmitting of such spectral bands does not require a guard band between them thus achieving high spectral efficiency and better utilization of the fiber band.
#Text=In the preferred embodiment the set of spectral bands is formed by an optical comb generator.
#Text=The data is embedded using OFDM with M-PSK modulation format, in the preferred embodiment it is QPSK format (quadrature phase shift keying).
#Text=Orthogonal frequency division multiplexing of the signal in each spectral band allows achieving high data rate transmission and improved robustness to the spectral dispersion and PMD.
